titleStmt.title: A vindication of Psalme 105.15. (touch not mine anoynted, and doe my prophets no harme) from some false glosses lately obtruded on it by Royallists. Proving that this divine inhibition was given to kings, not subjects; to restraine them from injuring and oppressing Gods servants, and their subjects; who are Gods anoynted, as well as kings: and that it is more unlawfull for kings to plunder and make war upon their subjects, by way of offence, then for subjects to take up armes against kings in such cases by way of defence. With a briefe exhortation to peace and unity.
titleStmt.author: Prynne, William, 1600-1669.

Please go to https://www.textcreationpartnership.org/ for more information about the project.

titleStmt.title: A vindication of Psalme 105.15. (touch not mine anoynted, and doe my prophets no harme) from some false glosses lately obtruded on it by Royallists. Proving that this divine inhibition was given to kings, not subjects; to restraine them from injuring and oppressing Gods servants, and their subjects; who are Gods anoynted, as well as kings: and that it is more unlawfull for kings to plunder and make war upon their subjects, by way of offence, then for subjects to take up armes against kings in such cases by way of defence. With a briefe exhortation to peace and unity.
titleStmt.author: Prynne, William, 1600-1669.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: A VINDICATION Of PSALME 105.15.
(Touch not mine Anoynted, and doe my Prophets no harme) from ≈øome fal≈øe Glo≈ø≈øes lately obtruded on it by Royalli≈øts.

PROVING, That this Divine Inhibition was given to Kings, not Subjects; to re≈øtraine them from injuring and oppre≈ø≈øing Gods ≈øervants, and their Subjects; who are Gods Anoynted, as well as Kings: And that it is more unlawfull for Kings to plunder and make War upon their Subjects, by way of offence, then for Subjects to take up Armes again≈øt Kings in ≈øuch ca≈øes by way of defence. With a briefe exhortation to peace and unity.

q.p: He that ruleth over men mu≈øt be ju≈øt, ruling in the feare of God.

I returned and con≈øidered all the Oppre≈ø≈øions that are done under the Sunne; and behold the teares of ≈øuch as were oppre≈ø≈øed, and they had no Comforter: and on the ≈øide of their oppre≈ø≈øors there was power, but they had no Comforter. Wherefore I prai≈øed the dead which are already dead, more then the living which are yet alive.

As a roaring Lyon, and a ranging Beare, ≈øo is a wicked Ruler over the poore people. The Prince that wanteth under≈øtanding is al≈øo a great oppre≈ø≈øour; but he that hateth covetou≈øne≈ø≈øe ≈øhall prolong his daies.
But if ye bite and devoure one another, take heed that ye be not con≈øumed one of another.

div.p: THere is nothing more pernicious to the ≈øouls of men, or de≈øtructive to the republique in di≈øtracted times, then Clergy-mens wre≈øting of Scriptures from their genuine ≈øen≈øe to en≈ønare mens con≈øciences, the better to accompli≈øh ≈øome ≈øini≈øter de≈øignes. How ≈øundry ≈øacred texts have been thus perverted of later yeers, not by the2 Pet. 2.16 unlearned and un≈øtable vulgar, but by the greate≈øt Seraphicall Doctors in our Church, is too apparent unto all; and among others that of the P≈øalmi≈øt, P≈øal. 105.15. (which is repeated 1 Chron. 16.22.) Touch not mine Anoynted, and do my Prophets no harm; hath not had the lea≈øt violence offered it, both in Pre≈ø≈øe and Pulpit, to cry up the ab≈øolute irre≈øi≈øtable Prerogative of Kings in all their exorbitant proceedings; and beat down the ju≈øt liberties of the Subject, without the lea≈øt defen≈øive oppo≈øition; when as this text, in real verity, is rather a direct precept given to Kings them≈øelves, not to oppre≈ø≈øe or injure their faithful ≈øubjects, then an injunction given to ≈øubjects, not to defend them≈øelves again≈øt the oppre≈ø≈øive de≈øtructive wars, and projects of their Princes. In which regard it wil be no un≈øea≈øonable nor ungratefull worke, to cleare this text from all fal≈øe Glo≈ø≈øes, and re≈øtore it to its proper con≈øtruction.

In former ages when popery domineered, the popi≈øh Clergy grounded their pretended exemption from all temporall juri≈ødiction on this Scripture; ≈øugge≈øting, that they onely, at lea≈øt principally were Gods Anointed here intended; and therefore ought not be touched nor apprehended by Kings or temporall Iudges for any crimes. But this fal≈øe Glo≈ø≈øe being long ≈øince exploded, many Court Divines, not ≈øo much to ≈øecure as flatter Kings, have applyed it primarily unto Kings, and ≈øecundarily to Prie≈øts, as meant of them alone, excluding their faithfull Subjects out of its protection and limits; when as the text is meant of none el≈øe but they in general, and of Abraham, I≈øaac, and Jacob, with their families in particular.

1. To put this out of que≈øtion: you mu≈øt fir≈øt ob≈øerve, that this P≈øalm from the 5 ver≈øe to the end, is meerely hi≈øtoricall. The 7 fir≈øt ver≈øes of it are but a gratulatory preamble (interlaced with ≈øome exhortations) to the ≈øub≈øequent hi≈øtoricall narration; as he that reads them advi≈øedly will at fir≈øt acknowledge: In the 8, 9, 10, & 11. ver≈øes, the P≈øalmi≈øt begins his hi≈øtory, with the covenant which God made to Abraham, and the oath which he ≈øware to I≈øaac; and confirmed the ≈øame unto Jacob for a law, and to I≈ørael for an everla≈øting te≈øtament: ≈øaying, unto thee will I give the land of Canaan, the lot of your inheritance. In the 12, 13, 14, & 15. ver≈øes, he expre≈ø≈øeth the ≈øpecial care and protection of God over Abraham, I≈øaac, and Jacob, and their ≈øeveral families after his covenant thus made unto them, in the≈øe words: When they (to wit, Abraham, I≈øaac, and Jacob, with their families) were but a few men in number, yea very few and ≈øtrangers in it: When they went from one Nation to another, from one Kingdom to another people (which cannot po≈ø≈øibly be expounded of Kings and Prie≈øts, but onely of tho≈øe Patriarcks) He ≈øuffered no man to doe them wrong, but reproved even Kings for their ≈øakes, ≈øaying, Touch not mine Aroynted, and doe my Prophets no harme. Then in the very next ver≈øe to the end of the P≈øalm, he proceeds with the ≈øtory of the famine in Egypt, and of Io≈øephs ≈øending thither beforehand by God, &c. So that by the expre≈ø≈øe words and ≈øeries of the ≈øtory in this P≈øalm, the≈øe per≈øons of whom God ≈øaid, Touch not mine anointed, and do my Prophets no harme, were Abraham, I≈øaac, and Iacob, and their families, (as S. Augu≈øtin with ≈øundry other Expo≈øiters of this P≈øalm conclude;) who in truth were neither Kings nor Prie≈øts by office, but onely Gods peculiar people and ≈øervants: of whom he took ≈øpecial care. Whence I thus rea≈øon, in the fir≈øt place.

The≈øe words, Touch not mine anointed, &c. were originally ≈øpoken and intended only of Abraham, I≈øaac, and Iacob, and their families, who were neither actual Kings not Prie≈øts; & they were meant of them, not as they were Kings or Prie≈øts, but only as they were the ≈øervants
and cho≈øen people of God; as is evident by the 6 ver≈øe of this P≈øalm, O ye ≈øeed of Abraham his SERVANT, ye children of Jacob his CHOSEN.
Therefore they are to be ≈øo interpreted; and to be applyed not to Kings and Prie≈øts, as they are ≈øuch; but only to the faithful ≈øervants and cho≈øen people of God, though, and as ≈øubjects.

Secondly, Con≈øider to whom the≈øe words were ≈øpoken; not to Subjects, but to Kings them≈øelves; as the P≈øalmi≈øt re≈øolves in expre≈ø≈øe terms, Ver≈ø. 14. He ≈øuffered no man to do them wrong, but reproved even KINGS for their ≈øakes; ≈øaying, (even to Kings them≈øelves) Touch not mine anointed, and do my Prophets no harme. Now that the≈øe words were ≈øpoken to Kings them≈øelves is apparent, by tho≈øe hi≈øtories to which the≈øe words relate, recorded at large, Gene≈ø. 12.10. to 20, Gen. 20. throughout, and Gen. 26.1. to 17. and ver≈ø. 29. Where when Abraham by rea≈øon of the famine went down into Egypt, with Sarah his wife, and King Pharaoh tooke her into his hou≈øe, God fir≈øt permitted neither Fharaoh nor his ≈øervants to do either of them any injury (though Abraham out of over-much feare, ≈øu≈øpected they would have killed him, and therefore made Sarah ≈øay ≈øhe was his ≈øi≈øter,) and likewi≈øe plagued Pharaoh, and his ≈øervants becau≈øe of Sarah Abrahams wife; whereupon they and all theirs went away in ≈øafety. After which Abraham and his wife ≈øojourning in Gerar, Abimelech king of Gerar ≈øent and took Sarah: But God ≈øaid to Abimelech in a dream, behold thou art a dead man for the woman that thou hast taken, for ≈øhe is a mans wife, &c. Therefore I ≈øufferred thee not to touch her: Now therefore re≈øtore the man his wife, for he is a Prophet: (where, Touch not mine anoynted, and do my Prophets no harme, were litterally fulfilled:) and he ≈øhal pray for thee, and thou ≈øhalt live; and if thou re≈øtore her not, know that thou ≈øhalt ≈øurely die, thou and all that are thine: whereupon Abimelech re≈øtored Abraham his wife, and gave him Sheep, Oxen, Men-≈øervants, and Women-≈øervants, and leave to dwell in the Land where he plea≈øed. After which I≈øaac and his wife dwelling in Gerar, and he telling the men of the place that ≈øhe was his ≈øi≈øter, le≈øt they ≈øhould kill him for her, becau≈øe ≈øhe was faire, king Abimelech di≈øcovering her to be his wife, charged all his people, ≈øaying, he that toucheth this man or his wife ≈øhall ≈øurely be put to death; yea he kindly intreated him, and did unto him nothing but good, and ≈øent her away in peace. To which we may adde, the ≈øtory of Gods prohibiting and re≈øtraing both Laban and E≈øau (who were as potent as Kings) to burt Jacob when they came out maliciou≈øly again≈øt him. Gen. 31.24, 29, 52.55. & ch. 33.1, 2, 3, 4, &c. This prohibition then, Touch not mine anoynted, &c. being given to Kings them≈øelves, not to touch or hurt the≈øe Patriarchs whiles they ≈øojourned among them as forraigners and ≈øubjects (as all expo≈øitours grant) and not to ≈øubjects touching their Kings; the≈øe two conclu≈øions will hence nece≈ø≈øarily follow.

1. That this inhibition, given to Kings them≈øelves with reference to ≈øubjects, and the people of God, cannot properly be meant of Kings and Prie≈øts, but of ≈øubjects fearing God. It is mo≈øt apparant, that Kings, Princes and Rulers of the earth have alwaies been the greate≈øt enemies and per≈øecutors of Gods anointed ones, to wit, of Chri≈øt and his cho≈øen members; witne≈ø≈øe P≈ø. 2.2. & Act. 3.26, 27. The Kings of the Earth ≈øet them≈øelves, and the Rulers take coun≈øell together again≈øt the Lord, & again≈øt his anoynted: For of a truth again≈øt the holy child Ie≈øus, whom thou ha≈øt anointed, both Herod and Pontius Pilate, with the Gentiles and people of I≈ørael were gathered together, &c. And now Lord behold their threatnings. Which truth you may ≈øee exemplified by P≈ø. 119.23, 161. Ier. 26.21, 22, 23. c. 36.26. c. 37.15. c. 38.4, 5, 6. Ezek. 22.6.7, 27, 28. Mich. 3.1. to 12 Zeph. 3 3.1 Sam. 22.16 to 20.2 Chron. 24 21.1 King. 22.26.27, c. 29.2.10. Rev. 17.12, 13, 14. c. 18 9, 10. c. 19.18, 19. Math. 10.17, 18 Lu. 21.12. Iam: 2.6. Act. 12.1, 2, 3. with ≈øundry other Scriptures, and by all eccle≈øia≈øtical hi≈øtories ≈øince. In which regard God in his infinite wi≈ødome gave this divine inhibition, not to ≈øubjects and inferiour per≈øons; but to Kings, Princes, and the greate≈øt Potentates (who, deem their wils a law, and think they may doe what they plea≈øe to their godly ≈øubjects,) Touch not mine anointed, and do my Prophets no harme: which being ≈øpoken to Kings them≈øelves; it cannot be meant of Kings but ≈øubjects; unle≈ø≈øe you wil make this non≈øence expo≈øition of it. That Kings mu≈øt not touch nor hurt them≈øelves; and that it is unlawfull for one King to make war again≈øt, impri≈øon, depo≈øe, or kill another:
which the practi≈øe of all ages, with infiniteRead the 2 Chr. 36. Dan. 5.30, 31. Jo≈øh. 12. for all the re≈øt. pre≈øidents in Scripture and ≈øtory, manife≈øt to be lawful, and not prohibited by this text; which can properly be applied to none, but ≈øubjects fearing God.

2. That all Gods faithfull people are Gods anoynted, as well as Kings: and therefore as our Court Cycophants conclude from hence, That Subjects may in no wi≈øe take up Armes (though meerely defen≈øive) again≈øt their Kings, becau≈øe they are Gods anoynted: ≈øo by the ≈øelf-≈øame rea≈øon, the genuine proper meaning and expre≈ø≈øe re≈øolution of this text, Kings ought not to take up Armes again≈øt their ≈øubjects, e≈øpecially tho≈øe profe≈ø≈øing the true feare of God, becau≈øe they are Gods anoynted to, as well as Kings.
If any Court-Chaplaine here demand; how I prove beleeving Subjects fearing God, to be hi≈ø annointed, as wel as Kings or Prie≈øts?

I an≈øwer: fir≈øt, the Scripture re≈øolves expre≈øly: That all true Chri≈øtians are really (in a ≈øpirituall ≈øence) both Rev. ‚Ä¢ . c. 5.10. c. 20.6. Exod. 19.6 1 Pet. 2.5. Kings and Prie≈øts to God the Father, though they be but ≈øubjects in a politicke ≈øence: yea, God hath prepared a heavenly kingdome, (with an eternal Crown of glory) for them, where they ≈øhall raigne with Chri≈øt for ever and ever. Math. 5.3. c. 25.34. Lu. 6.20. c. 12.32. c. 22.29.30. Col. 1.13.1 The≈ø. 2.12. Hebr. 12.28. Iam. 2.5.2 Pet. 1.11.2 Tim. 4.8.1 Pet. 5.4.1 Cor. 9.25. Reve. 22.5.2 Tim. 2.12. Being therefore thus really Kings and Prie≈øts, and having an heavenly Kingdom and Crown of glory, wherein they ≈øhall raigne with Chri≈øt for ever: in this regard they may as truly be called Gods anointed, as any Kings and Prie≈øts what≈øoever.

Secondly, all true Chri≈øtians are members of Chri≈øt and of his body, fle≈øh and bone; and made one with Chri≈øt, who dwelleth in them, and they in him, 1 Cor. 12.12, 17. Ephe≈ø. 1.22, 23. c. 3.17. c. 9.29, 30.32. Iohn 6 51. c. 17.21, 23. In which re≈øpect they are not onely ≈øtiled Chri≈øtians in Scripture, Act. 11.26. c. 26.28. 1 Pet. 4.16. But Chri≈øt him≈øelfe, 1 Cor. 10.12. Ephe≈ø. 4.12, 13. Now our Saviour him≈øelfe is ≈øtiled Chri≈øt in Scripture, in the ab≈øtract, by way of excellency, onely becau≈øe he is the Lords anointed; anointed with the oyle of gladne≈ø≈øe above his fellows. P≈øal. 45.7. P≈ø. 2.2. E≈øay 61.1. Act. 4.23. c. 10.38. Lu. 4.18. Heb. 1.9. Chri≈øtos in the Greek, ≈øignifying anointed in Engli≈øh, being derived from Chrio, to anoint: And Chri≈øtians had this very title given them, becau≈øe they are Chri≈øts members, and have a ≈øpirituallSee Ezek. 16.9. I anointed thee with oyle, &c. anoyntment in, by, and from Chri≈øt, and his Spirit, 1 Iohn 2.27. But the ANOYNTING which ye have received of him abideth in you, and ye need not any man teach you, but as the ≈øame ANOINTING teacheth you of all things. Therefore they are really and truely Gods anoynted, and may be as properly ≈øo phra≈øed, as any Kings and Prie≈øts what≈øoever.

Thirdly, the Scripture in direct terms oft cals Gods people, (though ≈øubjects) Gods anointed: as P≈øal. 28.8, 9. The Lord is their ≈øtrength, and he is the ≈øaving health of his anoynted. Now who tho≈øe are, is expre≈ø≈øed in the following words, Save thy people, ble≈ø≈øe thine inheritance, guide them and lift them up for ever. Gods people are here defined to be his anoynted. So P≈øal. 18.50. And ≈øheweth mercy to his anointed; (but who are they?) to David and to his ≈øeed for ever more, that is, to Chri≈øt and his elect children, here called Gods anointed, Habakuck. 3.13. Thou wente≈øt forth for the ≈øalvation of thy people, even for ≈øalvation with thine anointed. 2 Cor. 1.21. Now he which e≈øtabli≈øheth us in Chri≈øt, and hath anointed us, is God, &c. 1 Ioh. 2.27. The anointing which ye have received of him, abideth in you, &c. All the≈øe, with other Scriptures, thus re≈øolving Gods people (though ≈øubjects) to be his anointed ones; they may be properly ≈øaid to be the per≈øons ≈øpecified in this text. Touch not mine anointed; being an injunction given to Kings them≈øelves, and not meant of Kings, but of Gods people, as I have formerly manife≈øted.

I ≈øhal willingly and cordially profe≈ø≈øe, that Kings in ≈øacred writ, are commonly called, Gods anointed; becau≈øe they were u≈øually anointed with Oyle upon their inauguration to their Throns, 1 Sam. 10.1. c. 15, 17. c. 12.3, 5. c. 16, 3, c. 12.13. c. 24.6, 10. c. 26.6, 11.16, 23.2 Sam. 1.14, 16. c. 2.4, 7 1 King. 1.34, 39, 45. 2 King. 9.3, 6, 12. 2. Chron. 6.42. P≈øal. 20.6. P≈øal. 89.20, 38, 51. P≈øal. 92.12. P≈øal. 132.10, 17. E≈øay 45.1. Lam. 4.20. And in this regard their per≈øons are ≈øacred, and no violence
ought to be exerci≈øed upon their per≈øons, e≈øpecially by their ≈øubjects, as is cleare by the 1 Sam. 24.3. to 12, 17, 18, 19. ch. 26.7. to 25. 2 Sam. 1.2, to 17. And hereupon this text, Touch not mine anointed, and doe my Prophets no harme, though not properly meant of Kings, may yet be aptly applyed to their per≈øonal ≈øafety. But then I ≈øay, on the contrary part, That all Gods Saints and people, though ≈øubjects, are his anointed ones as wel as Kings; wherefore Kings mu≈øt no more offer violence to their per≈øons or e≈øtates (without legal conviction and ju≈øt cau≈øe) then they offer violence to their Kings, which I ≈øhall thus make cleare.

Fir≈øt, becau≈øe God hath given this expre≈ø≈øe injunction even to Kings them≈øelves, Touch not mine anointed, (that is your ≈øubjects, my faithful ≈øervants) and doe my Prophets no harme, P≈øal. 105.14, 15. 1 Chro. 16.21, 12. Prohibiting Abimelech, and he his ≈øubjects ≈øo much as to touch Abraham, Sarah, or I≈øaac, Gen. 20.6. c. 26, 11, 29.

Secondly, becau≈øe he that toucheth them (to doe them harme) toucheth the very apple of Gods eye. Zeph. 2.8. P≈øal. 17.8, 9. Deut. 32.9 10, 11. Yea, per≈øecuteth God, nay Chri≈øt him≈øelfe. E≈øay 63.9 Math. 25.45. Act. 9 4, 5. And what Kings, how great ≈øoever, may or dare touch or per≈øecute God and Chri≈øt, the King of Kings.

Thirdly, becau≈øe God him≈øelfe hath quite extirpated Kings and their po≈øterities, for offering violence to his ≈øervants, though their ≈øubjects. Thus Ahab, Iezabel, and their po≈øterity were de≈øtroyed, for putting Naboth to death, and ≈øeizing on his Vineyard wrongfully without cau≈øe, though under a pretext of law, 1 King. 21. & 22. 2 King. 9. So King Joa≈øh exciting his people to ≈øtone the prophet Zachariah without good cau≈øe, which they did at his commandement; the Princes and people who did it were ≈øoon after de≈øtroyed by the Syrians; and the Kings own ≈øervants con≈øpired again≈øt him for the blood of Zachariah, and ≈ølew him on his bed, and then buried him di≈øhonourably, not in the Sepulchre of the Kings, So as his prayer at his death (the Lord look upon it and require it) was fully executed on the King and people, 2 Chron. 24.20. to 27. Thus King Iehoahaz, Iehorachin, and Iehoiachim with all their Princes and people were carried away captive into Babylon, and de≈øtroyed, for mocking, abu≈øing, and de≈øpi≈øing Gods me≈ø≈øengers, prophets, and people, 2 Chron. 36.16, 17. Many ≈øuch in≈øtances might be added, but the≈øe may ≈øuffice; and that of the King of Babilon, E≈øay 14.4, 19.20, 21, 22.
